awd_titl_txt: Modeling of Nano-architected Electrodes with Elastic Instabilities: The Role of Buckling on Electrochemical Performance
awd_abstract_narration:
The development of next generation lithium-metal electrodes can revolutionize the energy storage industry as the theoretical energy density of these materials greatly overshadows current battery capabilities. In practice, however, the high-volume expansion of the host material due to lithium insertion/reaction results in large deformations and loads which can cause fracture, pulverization, and eventually device failure. This award will support research towards investigating the use of elastic instabilities, such as buckling, in the design of nano-architected battery electrodes. This research will promote the electrochemo-mechanical sciences by elucidating the way buckling can improve electrochemical and mechanical battery performance, and the degree of improvement. Critically, this research will enable experimentalists to rapidly prototype and test next generation electrodes as well as provide a clear guideline as to the potential benefits of these designs. Finally, the research performed is not restricted to Li-Ion electrodes but can improve our understanding of several chemo-mechanical systems such as systems for catalysis and solid oxide fuel cells amongst others, which will advance the national health, prosperity, and welfare. The research will have a broad impact on U.S. education where it will aid in the training of a diverse group of next generation undergraduate and graduate students with a multi-disciplinary understanding of mechanics of solids and electrochemistry. The training of such future scientists is critical to the U.S. energy industry. Finally, the award will support outreach to underrepresented K-12 students through the development of hands on experiments on the physics, manufacturing, and deployment of Li-Ion batteries for clean energy storage.

The development of next-generation Li-Ion electrodes relying on lithium-metals will necessarily require the means of accommodating the large deformations which are incurred by these materials during the lithiation process. Elastic instabilities, in particular buckling, is one possible mechanism whereby deformation of the material can be accommodated with limited generation of stresses. At present, however, there is no numerical tool to enable the rational design of nano-architected electrodes that buckle. Our approach will make use of two types of model: i) a detailed three-dimensional, fully-coupled finite element model which accurately resolves the transient behavior of these complex systems under experimentally accurate electrochemical boundary conditions, and ii) a simplified reduced order model which integrates enough physics to provide a reasonably accurate estimation of the electrochemical performance at a fraction of the computational cost. These models will be experimentally validated and applied towards developing novel designs and design guidelines for nano-architected electrodes which buckle.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this award is to formulate novel models for electro-chemo-mechanical systems to better understand how we can accommodate the large deformations induced by electrochemical reactions, namely Lithiation, in energy storage devices. In particular, next generation devices seek to use lithium-metal materials to improve energy density. However, these are accompanied by large elastic-plastic deformations.

One outcome of this work was the development of models for nano-architected electrode structures which harness elastic instabilities, in particular buckling, as a possible mechanism to accommodate the large electrochemically induced deformations while limiting the generation of stress and resulting damage of the material. We developed a detailed chemo-mechanical finite element simulation of a single buckling electrode structure which in turn informed the formulation of a novel reduced order model. The reduced order model allowed for the exploration of a large design space and the development of a phase-map of the possible deformation mechanisms that these systems will undergo for a given geometry and state of charge. The theoretical frameworks were validated in collaboration with experimentalists and shown useful in guided the design of these structures.

In-line with the broad objective of this work to enable next generation energy storage devices, we additionally focused on understanding the behavior of materials which store Lithium through electrochemical reactions, known as conversion materials, rather than through intercalation. These materials can store larger amounts of lithium but undergo complex sharp interface electrochemical reactions which lead to large volume changes and potentially damage. In this aspect of our work, we developed a fundamental theoretical framework for modeling the coupled phenomena of species diffusion, chemical reactions, and mechanical deformation. We applied this to modeling the lithiation and sodiation of iron disulfide (FeS2) crystals. Using our theory, we showed that mechanical stress plays a critical role on the manner in which these materials undergo lithiation/sodiation reactions and ultimately dictate the morphology of the reaction front. (See Figure)

Finally, with a focus on understanding the large multi-particle behavior of next generation energy storage devices, we developed a numerical framework for modeling the interaction of multiple particles in an all-solid-state architecture. Here we focused on the role of interfaces and developed a coupled chemo-mechanical surface finite element which can capture the non-local reaction kinetics as well as the possibility of interfacial mechanical decohesion. Using this framework, we demonstrated that mechanical damage can play a significant role in dictating the electrochemical performance of the system, and should be carefully considered. The theoretical framework developed can serve as a tool to guide the design of microstructures for these next generation all-solid-state energy storage devices.

The research component of this effort led to multiple conference presentations, 5 journal publications, and 1 Ph.D. thesis, as well as supporting the work of two additional Ph.D. students. Of particular impact, is the training of graduate and undergraduate students to be multi-disciplinary scientist bridging the fields of mechanics of materials and electrochemistry. Such a workforce will be critical to make the fundamental discoveries necessary to usher in the next generation of clean energy storage solutions.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/14/2022
Modified by: Claudio Di Leo

Image
  • Finite element simulation showing the sharp-interface lithiation (top row) and sodiation (bottom row) of iron disulfide (FeS2) crystals. Contours shown are of the phase-field reaction coordinate.
    Elsevier
    Copyrighted
    Claudio Di Leo
    Reaction induced deformation of Iron Disulfide Crystals
